item.title: The man who voted for Washington and Lincoln
item.description: John Phillips of Sturbridge, Massachusetts, lived to be 104 and has a unique place in U.S. history.

item.title: The Supreme Court’s chance to stop punting on transgender status
item.description: Cases provide an opportunity to protect girls’ sports and put constitutional questions to rest.

item.title: Maybe Trump the isolationist had imperial ambitions all along
item.description: The president is trapped in a Gilded Age bubble where tariffs and resource grabs are prized.

item.title: Trump’s surprising win for the climate
item.description: The plan to advance nuclear energy will help reduce dependence on fossil fuels.

item.title: Why should Trump consider recognizing Somaliland? Because it works.
item.description: The self-governing enclave in the Horn of Africa has free elections, a flag, currency — but only Israel has recognized it as a country.

item.title: Trump’s Venezuela policy is debatable. Maduro’s evil isn’t.
item.description: The United Nations credibly accused his government of committing crimes against humanity.

item.title: This election is a charade — and America should say so
item.description: With Myanmar’s three-round election underway, the ruling junta craves undeserved legitimacy.

item.title: Trans athletes head to the Supreme Court
item.description: Neither science, nor the American public, is on their side.

item.title: Gen Zers aren’t talking — and it could cost them
item.description: The problem runs deeper than social awkwardness.

item.title: Trump wisely takes a go-slow approach to Venezuelan democracy
item.description: Regenerating constitutional democracy in Venezuela would require intensive U.S. military involvement.

item.title: MAGA justice: Shoot first, don’t even ask questions later
item.description: Renée Good, Iranian protests, the Hungarian Revolution and “Fortunate Son,” in readers’ eyes.

item.title: Running deficits larger than during the Great Depression is reckless
item.description: A bipartisan group of House members are rallying behind a welcome and reasonable target for 2030.

item.title: Why people see what they want in protests and police shootings
item.description: Reflexively siding with or against law enforcement is folly.
